name: Idiopathic Progressive Facial Hemiatrophy (Parry-Romberg Syndrome)
chief_complaint: My face is shrinking on one side and it's getting worse over time
physical_findings: Progressive hemifacial tissue wasting (skin, fat, muscle, bone)

lab_results.MRI brain: Ipsilateral cerebral atrophy in 45% of cases

treatment: Microvascular free tissue transfer for volume restoration
prognosis: Progression typically stabilizes after 2-10 years, but existing damage is permanent. Reconstructive outcomes vary based on timing and extent of atrophy.
description: A rare neurocutaneous syndrome characterized by progressive shrinkage and degeneration of tissues beneath the skin, typically affecting one side of the face. The condition often begins in childhood or adolescence with unknown etiology, though autoimmune and sympathetic nervous system theories exist. The atrophy progresses through active and stable phases, affecting all tissue layers including bone in severe cases.
risk_factors: History of trauma to trigeminal nerve distribution
